incumbent Steven Rosenfeld and
Lisa Kuhar will vie for the office
of Treasurer of the Class of '76.
Pam Chevers, Sunny Choi, and
Jeff Weiss were elected Senior
Class Student Council
representatives.
Fink expressed his hope that
"the Centennial graduation will
be a landmark event at Hopkins."
As President, he will assume
responsibility for that function.

By ALAN HIRSCH
Repairs of the Glass Pavilion
of the Hopkins Union cannot be
made for at least a month
because the University does not
have a replacement for one of thc
two panes broken two week ago.
The specially -treated
Pillcington Glass panes are made
Only in England and shipment
will take anywhere from one to
three months.
Plant Operations Director Bill
Campbell said that leaving the
Pavilion wall unrepaired will not
create any problems since it is
securely boarded up.
Campbell also said that the
glass will probably be protected
or entirely replaced by plastic in
order to eliminate the problem.
"I seriously doubt that things
will stay as they are," Campbell
stated.
Campus security has increased
its patrols of the Union area, but
has not placed a permanent
watchman there, George
Weinbach, Security Director,
disclosed.

continuing to look into the
possibility of legal action against

building was under construction
that rock-throwing would not
pose a threat to the glass walls of

the pavilion.

Hopkins is still only "looking
into the
possibility of legal
action."

refused commend on the matter,
acknowledging only that the
University is investigating the
possibility.
"This will go slowly," said
Benton of the investigation into
legal action.
Sickler, reached at his office
yesterday morning, also refused
to comment on the matter.
He said that he has not been

contacted by the Univeristy
administration about the
problem recently, and that he
intends to reserve all statements
for the administration._

By BOB DANNER
The Student Council Selctions
Committee will chose today from
the three MSE Symposium topics
selected by undergraduates in
voting last week.
The winning proposals in the
balloting were: "Election 76:
Where are we headed after 200
years," "The dynamics of the
written media, or: the pen as the
sword," and "Mysticism, science
and human potential."
The Selections committee will
send its recommendation to the
Student Council, which will act
on it tomorrow night.
"Mysticism" received the most
votes, with 210, while "Pen as
the sword" got 193 votes, and
"Election '76" received 186.
Four other proposals got more
than 150 votes, and only three
totaled less than 100 in the field
of 13.
Selections Committee
Chairman Andy Fredman said
that vote totals will not be taken
into consideration tomorrow
when the committee decides on
the topic it will recommend to
the Council.
The Selections Committee will
consider the appeal of a topic, its
timeliness, and its educational
value, Fredman said.
The Selections process for the

Symposium topic this year was a
new one, approved by a student
vote in March. Under the new
system, the Selections
Committee screens the topics
initially and submits 80 per cent
to the student body, and then
selects one of the three topics
receiving a plurality in the
balloting.
Last year, the Selections
Committee filtered down the
original, pool of topics to four,
from which students selected the
symposium topic in a vote.

Several of the sponsors of this
year's proposals expressed
dissatisfaction with the selection
system, Fredman said.
Major complaints were: 1) that
all information about a proposal
should be disseminated to the
student body, 2) that too many
topics are submitted on the
ballot and 3) the Selections
Committee should not have the
final decision.
Fredman said that it is
inappropriate to release a speaker
list before the people involved

are contacted and recruited. He
stated that names of the student
who submitted proposals are and
should be withheld to prevent a
political selection.
Since this information is not
available to the public, Fredman
asserted that the Selections
Committee is therefore more
qualified to choose.

may not pick the best over all
topics submitted, but it will

Symposium topic didn't become completely clear until it was
applied in an election. After being asked last week to select
three topics fro'm a selected field without knowing who their
authors were, all so that the Student Council Selections Committee could have the final say anyway, we're sure that the

Under the earlier system, undergraduates selected the topic
from a screened field. Now the Selections Committee screens
the proposals before and after the voting, picking the winner
from among the top three vote-getters. As always, the names of
those students submitting topics was withheld during last
week's balloting.

before and after the student body has had its say. The original
purpose of allowing the committee to review the proposals prior
to voting was to weed opt frivolous or unmanageable proposals.

panel must review the judgement of the undergraduate student
body as well.

the names of the topics' authors. When students vote for a
topic, they want to know who is going to supervise it if it is
eventually selected. The present method forces students to vote
somewhat blindly, equipped with only half of what, by right,
they should know before making a selection. At present, evaluation of the proposals' sponsors is left up to the Selections Committee, a group of five SC reps. We propose that this forum be
expanded somewhat—like to include the entire student body.

public and the student body's vote made final, we feel that,
with the Selections Committee still allowed to screen out frivolous submissions, open campaigning would be better than the
disallowed sort that went on prior to last week's vote, disadvantaging those who chose to adhere to the committee's rules for
selection.

—part in determining who's going to run it.

The foolishness of the new method of selecting the MSE
Symposium topic didn't become completely clear until it was
applied in an election. After being asked last week to select
three topics fro'm a selected field without knowing who their
authors were, all so that the Student Council Selections Committee could have the final say anyway, we're sure that the
recently approved method is neither fair nor effective.
Under the earlier system, undergraduates selected the topic
from a screened field. Now the Selections Committee screens
the proposals before and after the voting, picking the winner
from among the top three vote-getters. As always, the names of
those students submitting topics was withheld during last
week's balloting.
We object first of all to the fact that the Selections Committee exercises unilateral jurisdiction over the field of submissions
before and after the student body has had its say. The original
purpose of allowing the committee to review the proposals prior
to voting was to weed opt frivolous or unmanageable proposals.
Now, apparently, The Student Council feels that its Selections
panel must review the judgement of the undergraduate student
body as well.
We also take exception to the present tactic of withholding
the names of the topics' authors. When students vote for a
topic, they want to know who is going to supervise it if it is
eventually selected. The present method forces students to vote
somewhat blindly, equipped with only half of what, by right,
they should know before making a selection. At present, evaluation of the proposals' sponsors is left up to the Selections Committee, a group of five SC reps. We propose that this forum be
expanded somewhat—like to include the entire student body.
Furthermore, we feel that the excessively bureaucratic format of the system—committee, then to vote, then to committee
to choose from the top three—will serve to discourage undergraduate interest in the Symposium selection. Student participation is, in fact minimal now, with the student body allowed to
give a worthless approbation that is subject to the final ministrations of the almighty Selections Committee.
Though some politicking might result if the names were made
public and the student body's vote made final, we feel that,
with the Selections Committee still allowed to screen out frivolous submissions, open campaigning would be better than the
disallowed sort that went on prior to last week's vote, disadvantaging those who chose to adhere to the committee's rules for
selection.
Since the Symposium is an important undergraduate function, undergraduates should play a larger—or at least more real
—part in determining who's going to run it.

Pioneers put JV lax to the test
The Hopkins JV Lacrosse team
braved the rain and a
second-quarter rally by their'
opponents and defeated the
Anne Arundel Community
College Pioneers 13-10 in a game
last Friday. The MV now has A
string of six victories against one
loss to their credit.
Against a tough Pioneer squad,
the Baby Jays opened up the
game on, a high note as Chuck
Clarvit scored first on an
unassisted drive to the goal. A
feed from Doober Aburn gave
Clarvit another goal a minute
later.
Winning the ensuing face-off,
Anne Arundel was able to
respond with a Dan Korbin goal
with 3:35 elapsed in the quarter.
Carl Yeich kept the Baby Jays

momentum going, scoring a goal
off the face-off. He was quickly
followed with tallies by Bryan
Chetalat and Joe Devlin.
Down 5-1 with less than half
of the first period gone, the
Pioneers dug in for battle.
Shutting the Baby Jays off
entirely for the rest of the
quarter and allowing them only
two goals in the second period,
Anne Arundel raced forward,
scoring two more goals in the
first quarter and four in the
second. The score at the half was
tied 7-7.
Faced with Anne Arundel's
surging momentum and a steady
downpour of rain that was
quickly turning their field into a
sea of mud, the Baby Jays'
decided it was their turn for a

rally. With attackman Doe Devlin
leading the charge, Hopkins
blitzed the Pioneers, scoring four
times and controlling the ball for
most of the third quarter. The
Pioneers were not able to recover
until late in the period when they
scored with 14:36 elapsed.
Too Late
By then, however, it was too
late.
Offensive leader for the game
was Joe Devlin with three goals
and one assist. Fellow attackman
Doober Aburn matched Devlin
for offensive points with one goal
and three assists.
The Baby Jays face local high
school power Worcester today at
3. Worcester, at present, is the
No. 2 ranked team in the state of
Maryland.
